s.text: Having declared war, the pundit posse immediately expressed doubt that it could be won.
Contemplating Saddam's anthrax-tipped warheads on NBC's Meet the Press , Rush Limbaugh answered his own question when he asked, should we "wait until he does it, or pre-empt it?"
"Clearly, we've got to strike the head," said Sam Donaldson on This Week . "[Saddam] must go," said Margaret Carlson on CNN's Capital Gang . "Extend the no-fly zone," said David Gergen.
"[Saddam], being a parolee, is not in a position to determine who his parole officer will be."
"[Saddam], being a parolee, is not in a position to determine who his parole officer will be."
"[Saddam], being a parolee, is not in a position to determine who his parole officer will be."
"[Saddam], being a parolee, is not in a position to determine who his parole officer will be."
"[Saddam], being a parolee, is not in a position to determine who his parole officer will be."
"[Saddam], being a parolee, is not in a position to determine who his parole officer will be."
"[Saddam], being a parolee, is not in a position to determine who his parole officer will be."
The same-sized package containing anthrax could kill half of the inhabitants of Washington, D.C., he warned.

Iraq absorbed 88,000 tons of bombs during the 43 days of the Gulf War without folding or replacing Saddam, noted several pundits, including Tim Russert on NBC's Meet the Press . Saddam's bio-chem arsenal was surely bunkered beyond the reach of U.S. bombs, they concluded.
